executive_summary: As a form of liability insurance, operators in the Medical Malpractice Insurance industry support physicians, nurses and other medical practitioners by offering protection when wrongful practices result in bodily injury, property damage and medical expenses. In the event of an allegation of negligence or a lawsuit, medical malpractice insurance covers expenses relating to defense attorney fees, court costs and settlements. Insurers can provide these services at a fraction of the potential loss by pooling premiums to pay for losses that some policyholders incur. Accordingly, the industry is an indispensable part of risk management for the overall healthcare industry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Industry performance grown over five years to 2021
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Medical Malpractice Insurance industry's performance grown over the five years to 2021, as a result of medical improvements and policy changes. Demand for insurance products provided by operators is relatively constant since the industry has grown alongside the broader healthcare sector.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 pandemic supported steady revenue growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic has supported steady industry revenue growth since 2020, even as the Healthcare sector has been disrupted. While demand for healthcare services has declined due to COVID-19 treatments placed on the healthcare system, this growth in premiums has allowed both industry revenue and profit to increase during the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Revenue expected to rise at annualized rate of 1.3%
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry revenue is expected to rise at an annualized rate of 1.3% to $9.9 billion over the five years to 2026. While medical advances continue to improve outcomes, lowering risk for patients, industry operators are expected to seek out increase premiums by offering additional products and services that more accurately forecast risk.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Moderate industry growth expected over next 5 years
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Medical Malpractice Insurance industry is expected to grow at a moderate pace over the five years to 2026, as the industry adapts to the changing healthcare landscape. Innovation regarding patient care is not expected to slow, however, technology used to track these changes will likely improve, enabling operators to better monitor trends.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COVID-19 treatment may limit demand early on
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Medical treatment of COVID-19 (coronavirus) patients will likely limit demand early in the period. As outbreaks of new variants continue into the outlook period, physicians will continue to treat large numbers of COVID-19 patients. However, as treatment guidelines are established, there will be less chance of malpractice when treating the virus.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Technology trends to persist and accelerate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Trends in technology that occurred over the five years to 2021 are expected to persist and accelerate during the outlook period. Accordingly, as the number of mobile internet connections increases, investment in telemedicine companies will likely follow.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Uncertain conditions around health insurance coverage
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of people with private health insurance is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 0.3% over the five years to 2026, while the health eating index is anticipated to rise an annualized 0.5% during the same period. This combination of low health coverage with healthier eating will likely lower the chance for malpractice claims to occur.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Premiums are typically highest for surgeons, as surgery carries a high level of risk. Surgery accounts for the second-largest number of malpractice lawsuits, but surgeons can also be subject to misdiagnosis or treatment-related malpractice cases. Additionally, any surgery that is unsuccessful may result in an investigation, which can lead to higher costs for insurance providers. Anesthesiologists are also vulnerable to malpractice lawsuits, as anesthesia is a common area for mistakes and accidents in surgeries.

Aside from surgery, there are many areas of medicine where malpractice can occur. Diagnosis, treatment, prescriptions and other areas of general medical care can all be subject to malpractice lawsuits. Nearly all physicians, regardless of specialty, can be involved in these types of malpractice cases. As a result, internal medicine physicians account for one of the largest markets for malpractice insurance, since this is one of the largest areas of medical care.

Physicians with other specialties can experience relatively high premiums depending on the risk associated with their field. For example, pediatricians and family care doctors experience moderately high premiums, since malpractice involving children can result in high payouts for plaintiffs.
Radiologists have high premiums, since misread X-rays are a common way for a patient's condition to be misdiagnosed.
All other specialties account for 18.3% of revenue in 2021.

products_and_services.product_description: The majority of medical malpractice lawsuits are related to diagnosis. These lawsuits can occur when a patient alleges that a condition was either misdiagnosed or diagnosed later than it should have been.

Surgery is the second-largest area for malpractice lawsuits, as surgery carries a high level of risk. While patients can die during surgery without malpractice occurring, an unsuccessful surgery can result in malpractice investigations.

Malpractice lawsuits regarding the general treatment of a patient account for a significant portion of malpractice payouts. Malpractice in regard to treatment occurs when a doctor provides substandard or unnecessary healthcare that results in injury, pain or the death of a patient.

Obstetrics has also increased as a share of revenue over the past five years, accounting for 10.0% of revenue in 2021. Since most major malpractice lawsuits are single isolated incidents, a majority of cases that have awarded claims over $1.0 million involve the field of obstetrics since an injury at birth can result in life long disabilities.
All other malpractice lawsuits account for 13.0% of revenue in 2021.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: In the Medical Malpractice Insurance industry, demand is relatively inelastic since many states require doctors to have medical malpractice insurance to practice medicine. These requirements can involve having a minimum level of coverage, or having some form of coverage to qualify for state benefits.

Even in states where malpractice insurance is not required, most doctors and healthcare providers choose to have coverage to avoid financial ruin if they experience a malpractice lawsuit. As a result, industry demand is largely determined by the number of practicing physicians.

Malpractice regulation, and what courts determine counts as malpractice, can also drive demand. If it becomes easier for patients to sue doctors for malpractice, insurance will likely become increasingly necessary for doctors.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 30%) and population (around 25%) compared to other regions. Contribution to industry revenue also drives the Mid-Atlantic region, which is expected to account for 28.6% of revenue in 2021, making it the largest region in the industry.

The Southeast region has around 15% of establishments and around 20% of the population. Meanwhile, the Southeast is the second-largest contributor to industry revenue with 22.2% of revenue in 2021, as this is the most populated region, and therefore, has the largest healthcare sector.
The Great Lakes region has around 15% of establishments and around 15% of the population.
The West region has around 10% of establishments and around 15% of the population.
New England has around 10% of establishments and around 5% of the population.
The Southwest region has around 10% of establishments and around 10% of the population.
The Plains region has around 5% of both establishments and population.
The Rocky M region has the lowest percentage of around 5% for both establishments and population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: States often set laws regarding malpractice insurance premiums, typically in states that require doctors to purchase malpractice insurance.
As insurance providers, industry enterprises are subject to the same regulations that govern all other insurance companies.

barriers_points.barrier_description: States are strict with the companies that provide malpractice insurance, requiring certain levels of cash reserves. Companies must have money available as soon as they take on clients.
Malpractice insurance providers must have a high level of expertise in malpractice and medicine to ensure clients are qualified and receive proper coverage.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies often work directly with hospitals and negotiate deals in which all doctors working for a hospital can acquire the same malpractice insurance. Large companies are able to maintain larger reserves for payouts and negotiate better deals with healthcare providers.
Some hospital networks and group practices combine resources to provide doctors with a fund for malpractice cases, but these group legal funds do not pose a significant threat to the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Companies mainly operate on a regional basis, enabling enterprises to gain high market share within particular geographic markets while keeping total market share low.
Over the five years to 2026, market share concentration is expected to grow as the largest companies pursue acquisitions to expand their presence.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Loss and loss adjustment expenses (LLAEs) refer to an insurer's claim liabilities, including costs associated with making benefit payments to policyholders. According to IBISWorld, LLAEs are expected to account for 67.8% of industry premiums in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Medical Malpractice Insurance industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity. In 2021, IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, the industry will allocate $0.09 to capital investment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatility dependent on aggregate premium changes
volatility_points.volatility_description: Volatility is dependent on aggregate changes in premiums, which is, in turn, driven by broader trends in the healthcare field.
Improvements in both policy underwriting as insurers have more advanced modeling capabilities to forecast risk, which can incorporate different medical practices.
As the COVID-19 pandemic spreads, causing spikes in hospitalizations, both premiums and payouts may increase temporarily until more treatment information is available.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The technology used generally consists of basic digital recordkeeping software to maintain client records and coverage levels.
Insurance providers use algorithms to more easily determine premiums for new clients, reducing labor demand and risk of human error.

FAQs.question: How has demand for telehealth services affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Medical malpractice insurers who focus on providing insurance via the internet have been able to more competitively price policies due to lower operations expenses.

FAQs.question: How diversified are your product offerings compared to competitors?
FAQs.answer: Product line diversification of medical malpractice insurers largely depends on the size of the company.

FAQs.question: What international operations do you conduct and how could you benefit from increasing your international reach?
FAQs.answer: Very few property and casualty insurers operate internationally due to regulatory constraints as well as an unfamiliarity with the insurance needs of international consumers.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are your establishments more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: Most medical malpractice insurers provide one or a handful of lines of insurance to consumers in a specific part of the country, while some operators have the scale to operate nationwide.

FAQs.question: To what extent are your processes automated and how do you plan on investing in automation over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: While some analytic tools have been in the property and casualty underwriting process, companies still rely on highly skilled workers.

FAQs.question: How do you expect changes to tort reform to effect your business?
FAQs.answer: Tort reform differs from state to state and limits the amount liability for practitioners which lowers their risk.

FAQs.question: What states are licensed to work in?
FAQs.answer: Medical malpractice laws differ significantly from state to state.

FAQs.question: To what extent are you affected by hospital reinsurers?
FAQs.answer: Large hospitals have begun to self-insure their physicians.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins vary between medical malpractice insurers based on the size of the businesses, the region they operate in and the lines of insurance they provide.

FAQs.question: How often do you payout lawsuits? Has your income fluctuated greatly in recent years due to payouts?
FAQs.answer: As an insurance providers, industry companies lose income when they have to payout in lawsuits.

FAQs.question: Do you provide training or information on medical law? How do your employees stay up to date on medicine and medical law?
FAQs.answer: Malpractice insurance providers must have an extensive knowledge of medicine and the laws surrounding it.

FAQs.question: Are you located to any major hospitals? Do you work with any specific medical groups?
FAQs.answer: Malpractice insurance providers typically operate regionally, so having a large healthcare sector supports demand.

FAQs.question: How has telemedicine affected your premiums? Have you used telemedicine?
FAQs.answer: Telemedicine has increased as the number of mobile internet connections increases reducing unnecessary risk during procedures.

FAQs.question: How has rising health consciousness affected your business? Have you noticed more or less people in need of medical attention due to healthier eating?
FAQs.answer: People that have healthier diets are more likely to have better outcomes after a procedure.

FAQs.question: How much capital do you set aside for major lawsuits?
How has your profitability been affected by recent major product recalls?
FAQs.answer: While rare, major side effects of prescription medications can occur several years after taking them, causing significant harm.
